EDITORS COMMENTS

Ugo Foscolo: The Italian Exile (1778-1827) This portrait captures Ugo Foscolo, the renowned Italian writer, at the age of 38. Born in Zakynthos, Greece, on January 14, 1778, Foscolo was a man of immense intellectual curiosity and literary talent. His Italian heritage, however, was a source of both pride and exile. Foscolo's formative years were spent in Venice, where he was educated in the city's renowned schools. His literary prowess was evident from an early age, and he published his first poem, "Ode to Venice," at the age of 17. The poem's critical success brought Foscolo to the attention of the Venetian authorities, who saw his writings as a threat to their rule. In 1801, Foscolo was forced to flee Italy, leaving behind his family and his beloved Venice. He spent the next two decades in exile, traveling extensively throughout Europe, living in England, France, and Switzerland. Despite the hardships of exile, Foscolo continued to write, producing works of poetry, prose, and drama that would cement his place in Italian literature. This portrait, taken during Foscolo's exile, captures the intensity and passion that marked his life and work. His piercing gaze and serious expression convey a deep sense of introspection and intellectual rigor. The portrait also serves as a reminder of the sacrifices and struggles that often accompany artistic and intellectual pursuits. Ugo Foscolo's legacy endures to this day. His works continue to be read and studied, and his influence can be seen in the works of later Italian writers and thinkers. This portrait offers a glimpse into the life of a man who, despite the challenges of exile, remained committed to his art and his homeland.
